title: quarto-tutorial
text:
Adding text
In this part, we will use quarto to display our project goals. In index.qmd, create an introduction where you will state:
In this project we aim to visualize the trends of the most frequently used babynames from 1880 to 2017 in the United States. We do this by:
- Understanding the different columns of the data set
- Find the top 10 most frequently used baby names in the data for:
    - girls
    - boys
- Plot the yearly trend of the top 10 baby names

title: Analysis
text:
loadpackages and create data:

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r

plot results

fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()




Figure 1: cool plot with circles




In Figure 1 you can see cool circles
Now we re-create the above plot without showing the actual code in the rendered file. However, there will be an option to show the code!


Code
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()





Figure 2: the same cool plot with circles
